q: How does Sankhya differ from Advaita Vedanta?
a:
Sankhya and Advaita Vedanta are two philosophical systems in Hinduism with some significant differences.

Sankhya posits two fundamental realities: Purusha (consciousness) and Prakriti (material universe). According to Swami Sarvapriyananda, in Sankhya, Purusha and Prakriti are considered to be interacting with each other. This perspective is somewhat similar to Panpsychism, a philosophical position stating that consciousness, at some level, is a fundamental aspect of all things.

On the other hand, Advaita Vedanta, when referring to Purusha, understands it as Nirguna Brahman, which means attributeless Ultimate Reality or the absolute consciousness. In this context, Nirguna Brahman is not mentioned in the Sankhya philosophy.

Another distinction between the two systems is the concept of Jnana and Vijnana. While the lecture recording mentioned that it would be explained in detail later, Swami Sarvapriyananda briefly mentions that there was a discussion on this topic. Generally, Jnana refers to knowledge or awareness, while Vijnana implies a more profound and direct realization or understanding.

In summary, Sankhya and Advaita Vedanta differ in their understanding of Purusha (consciousness), the relationship between Purusha and Prakriti (material universe), and the concepts of Jnana and Vijnana. Advaita Vedanta's Purusha is equivalent to Nirguna Brahman, while Sankhya's Purusha is closer to the Panpsychism perspective. The two systems will be further elaborated on in later chapters of the Bhagavad Gita.

r.content: consciousness. These are the major differences between Sankhya and Advaita Vedanta. So, moment you say Purusha, Advaita Vedanta, they will say Purusha is Nirguna Brahman. But, they will understand Purusha in the Advaitic sense, not in the Sankhyan sense. I missed the first lecture in seventh chapter, waiting for the recording. It will be uploaded and there I explained the difference between Jnana and Vijnana. There was a lot of discussion on that. Yes, it will come. Girish says, is Panpsychism equivalent to Vishistha Advaita? Not equivalent, but pretty close, I would say. More than Vishistha Advaita, I would say Panpsychism is pretty close to Sankhya. What does Sankhya say? Here is a material universe and also consciousness, fundamental independent reality interacting with the material universe. Almost the same thing that Panpsychism is saying, what David Chalmers is trying to propose. When you experience God, it is still an object. Also, how does Kshetra and Kshetra get in? Very good question. This is the foundation for the Kshetra and Kshetragya, field and knower of the field, which will come in the 13th chapter. What he has just said, lower nature, the field, higher nature, the knower of the field. The Jiva is the Kshetragya, knower of the field. And all the lower nature, which he mentioned, the five elements, mind, intellect, ego, all of that is the field. So, he will call this field and field knower in the 13th chapter. Same idea. Nirguna is not mentioned here, Bill
